member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Batches.NBatch
member.summary: The NBatch class represents a set of diagram items and serves as base class for more specialized batches
member.remarks: Before using a batch you must call the Build method, which takes only one parameter - the diagram items from which the batch must be built

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Batches.NBatchLayout
member.summary: The NBatchLayout class is used to provide transaction based layout operations
member.remarks:
The Build method filters the building nodes for valid bounds. Once the batch is built you can execute the following set of layout commands:
Alignment helps you align nodes to a virtual grid, align their lefts, rights, tops and bottoms as well as align their centers and middles
Resize helps you size to nodes to a virtual grid, make their size, width and height identical, as well as increase the nodes width and height
Horizontal spacing helps you increase, decrease, remove and make equal the horizontal spacing of nodes
Vertical spacing helps you increase, decrease, remove and make equal the vertical spacing of nodes
Center in document helps you center the nodes horizontally or vertically in the document

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGrouping
member.summary: Base class for all data grouping algorithms.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGrouping.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGrouping.Classify(Nevron.Nov.DataStructures.INList{System.Double},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the specified number of data ranges (classes) for the given set of data points (distinct values).
member.returns: An array of doubles representing the data ranges. For example an array {0, 12, 32.1} means that there are 3 data ranges: [0, 12), [12, 32.1) and [32.1, Infinity).

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGrouping.RoundedRanges
member.summary: Determines whether to round the ranges calculated in the Classify method or not. By default set top false. Note that the rounding of the data ranges will produce "nicer" numbers for the map legend but may alter the way the algorithm clssifies the data points. So it is recommended not to use rounding for a small number of data points.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGroupingEqualDistribution
member.summary: Also known as quantiles, this method allows for unequally sized data intervals and involves adjustment of the interval limits until an equal number of data points can be slotted into each interval.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGroupingEqualDistribution.Classify(Nevron.Nov.DataStructures.INList{System.Double},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the specified number of data ranges (classes) for the given set of data points (distinct values).
member.param: The data points to classify sorted in ascending order.
member.returns: An array of doubles representing the data ranges. For example an array {0, 12, 32.1} means that there are 3 data ranges: [0, 12), [12, 32.1) and [32.1, Infinity).

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGroupingEqualInterval
member.summary: Also known as equal ranges (or steps), this method involves division of the entire data range into equally sized intervals.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGroupingEqualInterval.Classify(Nevron.Nov.DataStructures.INList{System.Double},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the specified number of data ranges (classes) for the given set of data points (distinct values).
member.param: The data points to classify sorted in ascending order.
member.returns: An array of doubles representing the data ranges. For example an array {0, 12, 32.1} means that there are 3 data ranges: [0, 12), [12, 32.1) and [32.1, Infinity).

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGroupingOptimal
member.summary: Uses the Jenks-Caspall optimal data grouping algorithm.
member.remarks: The algorithm is based on iterative re-cycling: the values on the edge of each class, with the mean of their own class and the average of the next class. If a value closer to the mean of the neighboring class, it will be moved into this. The process is repeated iteratively until no further optimization is possible.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NDataGroupingOptimal.Classify(Nevron.Nov.DataStructures.INList{System.Double},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the specified number of data ranges (classes) for the given set of data points (distinct values).
member.param: The data points to classify sorted in ascending order.
member.returns: An array of doubles representing the data ranges. For example an array {0, 12, 32.1} means that there are 3 data ranges: [0, 12), [12, 32.1) and [32.1, Infinity).

member.summary: The record represents a closed shape.

member.summary: Unused. The record represents a measured shape.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.ENShapefileRecordType.PolygonZ
member.summary: Unused. The record represents a closed, three-dimensional shape.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.ENShapefileRecordType.PolyLine
member.summary: The record represents a line connected by two or more points.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NAitoffProjection
member.summary: The Aitoff projection is a modified azimuthal map projection.
member.remarks: Proposed by David A. Aitoff in 1889, it is the equatorial form of the azimuthal equidistant projection, but stretched into a 2:1 ellipse while halving the longitude from the central meridian.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NCylindricalEqualAreaProjection
member.summary: Represents the general Cylindrical Equal-Area projection.
member.remarks: The following is a summary of cylindrical equal-area projection's special cases: - Lambert : standard parallel of 0 degrees - Behrmann : standard parallel of 30 degrees - Tristan Edwards : standard parallel of 37.383 degrees - Peters : standard parallel of 44.138 degrees - Gall : standard parallel of 45 degrees - Balthasart : standard parallel of 50 degrees

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NEckertIVProjection
member.summary: The Eckert IV projection, used for world maps, is a pseudocylindrical and equal-area.
member.remarks: The central meridian is straight, the 180th meridians are semi-circles, other meridians are elliptical. Scale is true along the parallel at 40:30 North and South.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NEckertIVProjection.ProjectPoint(Nevron.Nov.Graphics.NPoint)
member.summary: Projects the specified point.
member.returns: The transformed point.

member.summary: Deprojects the specified point to recover its longitude and lattitude.

member.summary: Returns a System.String that represents the current System.Object.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NEckertVIProjection
member.summary: The Eckert VI projection, used for maps of the world, is pseudocylindrical and equal area.
member.remarks: The central meridian and all parallels are at right angles, all other meridians are sinusoidal curves. Shape distortion increases at the poles. Scale is correct at standard parallels of 49:16 North and South.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NEckertVIProjection.ProjectPoint(Nevron.Nov.Graphics.NPoint)

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NHammerProjection
member.summary: The Hammer projection is an equal-area map projection, described by Ernst Hammer in 1892.
member.remarks: Directly inspired by the Aitoff projection, Hammer suggested the use of the equatorial form of the Lambert azimuthal equal-area projection instead of Aitoff's use of the azimuthal equidistant projection. Visually, the Aitoff and Hammer projections are very similar but the Hammer has seen more use because of its equal-area property.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NKavrayskiyVIIProjection
member.summary: The Kavrayskiy VII is a map projection invented by V. V. Kavrayskiy in 1939 for use as a general purpose pseudocylindrical projection.
member.remarks: Like the Robinson projection, it is a compromise intended to produce good quality maps with low distortion overall. It scores well in that respect compared to other popular projections, such as the Winkel Tripel, despite straight, evenly-spaced parallels and a simple formulation. It has been used in the former Soviet Union but is almost unknown in the Western world.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NKavrayskiyVIIProjection.ProjectPoint(Nevron.Nov.Graphics.NPoint)
member.summary: Projects the specified point.
member.returns: The transformed point.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NMercatorProjection
member.summary: Implements the Mercator projection.
member.remarks: This map projection introduced in 1569 by Gerardus Mercator. It is often described as a cylindrical projection, but it must be derived mathematically. The meridians are equally spaced, parallel vertical lines, and the parallels of latitude are parallel, horizontal straight lines, spaced farther and farther apart as their distance from the Equator increases. This projection is widely used for navigation charts, because any straight line on a Mercator-projection map is a line of constant true bearing that enables a navigator to plot a straight-line course. It is less practical for world maps because the scale is distorted; areas farther away from the equator appear disproportionately large. On a Mercator projection, for example, the landmass of Greenland appears to be greater than that of the continent of South America; in actual area, Greenland is smaller than the Arabian Peninsula.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NMercatorProjection.ProjectPoint(Nevron.Nov.Graphics.NPoint)
member.summary: Projects the specified point.
member.returns: The transformed point.

member.summary: Deprojects the specified point to recover its longitude and lattitude.

member.summary: Returns a System.String that represents the current System.Object.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NMillerCylindricalProjection
member.summary: The Miller cylindrical projection is a modified Mercator projection, proposed by Osborn Maitland Miller (1897-1979) in 1942.
member.remarks: The parallels of latitude are scaled by a factor of 0.8, projected according to Mercator, and then the result is divided by 0.8 to retain scale along the equator.

member.summary: Projects the specified point.
member.returns: The transformed point.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NMollweideProjection
member.summary: The Mollweide projection is a pseudocylindrical map projection generally used for global maps of the world (or sky). Also known as the Babinet projection, homolographic projection, or elliptical projection.
member.remarks: As its more explicit name Mollweide equal area projection indicates, it sacrifices fidelity to angle and shape in favor of accurate depiction of area. It is used primarily where accurate representation of area takes precedence over shape, for instance small maps depicting global distributions.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NOrthographicProjection
member.summary: Orthographic projection is a perspective (or azimuthal) projection, in which the sphere is projected onto a tangent plane. It depicts a hemisphere of the globe as it appears from outer space. The shapes and areas are distorted, particularly near the edges, but distances are preserved along parallels.
member.remarks: You can control the center point of the projection using the property.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NRobinsonProjection
member.summary: The Robinson projection is a map projection made in 1988 to show the entire world at once. It was specifically created in an attempt to find the good compromise to the problem of readily showing the whole globe as a flat image.
member.remarks: The projection is neither equal-area nor conformal, abandoning both for a compromise. The creator felt this produced a better overall view than could be achieved by adhering to either. The meridians curve gently, avoiding extremes, but thereby stretch the poles into long lines instead of leaving them as points. Hence distortion close to the poles is severe but quickly declines to moderate levels moving away from them. The straight parallels imply severe angular distortion at the high latitudes toward the outer edges of the map, a fault inherent in any pseudocylindrical projection.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NRobinsonProjection.ProjectPoint(Nevron.Nov.Graphics.NPoint)
member.summary: Projects the specified point.
member.returns: The transformed point.

member.summary: Deprojects the specified point to recover its longitude and lattitude.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NRobinsonProjection.ToString
member.summary: Returns a System.String that represents the current System.Object.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NStereographicProjection
member.summary: The stereographic projection is a particular mapping (function) that projects a sphere onto a plane.
member.remarks: The fact that no map from the sphere to the plane can accurately represent both angles (and thus shapes) and areas is the fundamental problem of cartography. In general, area-preserving map projections are preferred for statistical applications, because they behave well with respect to integration, while angle-preserving (conformal) map projections are preferred for navigation. The stereographic projection falls into the second category.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NVanDerGrintenProjection
member.summary: The van der Grinten projection is neither equal-area nor conformal. It projects the entire Earth into a circle, though the polar regions are subject to extreme distortion.

remarks.para: The projection was the first of four proposed by Alphons J. van der Grinten in 1904, and, unlike most projections, is an arbitrary geometric construction on the plane. It was made famous when the National Geographic Society adopted it as their reference map of the world from 1922 until 1988.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Import.Map.NWinkelTripelProjection
member.summary: The Winkel Tripel projection (Winkel III) is a modified azimuthal map projection proposed by Oswald Winkel in 1921. The projection is the arithmetic mean of the equirectangular projection and the Aitoff projection.
member.remarks: Goldberg and Gott show that the Winkel Tripel is arguably the best overall whole-earth map projection known, producing very small distance errors, small combinations of ellipticity and area errors, and the smallest skewness of any map. In 1998, the Winkel Tripel projection replaced the Robinson projection as the standard projection for world maps made by the National Geographic Society.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NGraphLayout
member.summary: The NGraphLayout class represents a regioned layout, whose regions are graphs. It serves as a base class for all graph layouts.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NGraphLayoutBase`1
member.summary:
A layout, which serves as base class for graph and tree layouts.
Common for graph and tree layouts is that they split the input graphinto connected graphs regions (e.g. graph and tree forests), which are subject to arrangement by the primary layout algorithm.
When the content of all regions is arranged, the regions are optionally arranged with the layout specified by the RegionLayout property. By default this property holds an instance of the NFlowLayout class.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NBarycenterForce
member.summary: The NBarycenterForce class represents an edge force, which tries to place connected vertices at their barycenter (center of gravity)
member.remarks:
The barycenter force is attractive by definition. It tries to collapse the vertices to the center of their mass. The force magnitude experienced by the vertices is specified by the following formulas:
vertex1Force = AttractionCoefficient * vertex1.Mass / (vertex1.Mass + vertex2.Mass)
vertex2Force = AttractionCoefficient * vertex2.Mass / (vertex1.Mass + vertex2.Mass)
The Mass parameter can be specified on a per vertex basis. If a vertex does not provide a concrete value for this parameter it is by default considered to be 1.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NForce
member.summary: The NForce class serves as base class for all types of forces, which can be used in force directed layouts
member.remarks:
Each force can be enabled or disabled, which is controlled by the Enabled property. When disabled the force will not be taken into account by the force directed layout. This lets you easily turn on/off different force configurations.
Provided that the force is enabled, it activates at the pass, specified by the ActivationPass property. The force directed layout will perform as many passes as the maximum ActivationPass setting of all currently enabled forces.

member.remarks: The bounce back force magnitute is computed by the following formula: RepulsionCoefficient * Math.Sqrt(IntersectionArea)

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NDesiredDistanceForce
member.summary: The NDesiredDistanceForce is a force, which couples an attraction force (edge force), and a repulsion force (vertex force). The two forces balance each other when the distance between connected vertices is equal to the specified desired distance.
member.remarks:
The attraction force magnitute is computed by the following formula:
AttractionCoefficient * Math.Pow(distance, 2) / Math.Pow(DesiredDistance, 2)
The repulsion force magnitute is computed by the following formula:
RepulsionCoefficient * Math.Pow(DesiredDistance, 2) / Math.Pow(distance, 2)
Provided that the RepulsionCoefficient and AttractionCoefficient are equal, the two forces balance each other at DesiredDistance.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NElectricalForce
member.summary: The NElectricalForce class represents a vertices force, which simulates the electrical repulsion between two ellectrically charged particles.
member.remarks:
The ellectrical force magnitute is computed by the following formula:
RepulsionCoefficient * vertex1.ElectricalCharge * vertex2.ElectricalCharge / Math.Pow(distance, 2)
Provided that the electrical charges are equal in sign (which is the most common case), the ellectrical force is repulsive and decreases in an inverse square law as the distance between the vertices is increased.
The ElectricalCharge parameter can be specified on a per vertex basis. If a vertex does not provide a concrete value for this parameter it is by default considered to be 1.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NGravityForce
member.summary: The NGravityForce class represents a global force, which simulates a gravity attraction to the current barycenter of the graph
member.remarks:
The gravity force simulates an attraction to the current barycenter of the graph, which is experienced by all vertices in the graph. The force magnitude is computed by the following formula:
AttractionCoefficient * (1 + vertex.Degree * DegreeFactor) * (Barycenter - vertex.Center)

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NMagneticFieldForce
member.summary: The NMagneticFieldForce is an edge force, which is used to impose an edge orientation constrain
member.remarks:
The magnetic force magnitute is computed by the following formula:
TorsionCoefficient * Math.Pow(distance, DistancePower) * Math.Pow(angle, AnglePower)
where angle is the angle, which the edge forms with the magnetic field.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NSpringForce
member.summary: The NSpringForce class represents an edge force, which simulates a spring connecting adjacent vertices.
member.remarks:
The spring force magnitude formula can take two forms based on the SpringForceLaw property value:
Logarithmic
edge.SpringStiffness * Math.Log(distance / edge.SpringLength)
HookeLaw
edge.SpringStiffness * (d - edge.SpringLength)
In both forms the spring force becomes repulsive, if the distance is smaller than the spring length, and becomes attractive, when the distance is larger than the spring length. That is, the spring force aims to make the distance between connected vertices equal to the natural (zero energy) of the spring.
The SpringStiffness and SpringLength parameters can be specified on a per edge basis. If an edge does not provide a concrete value for either of these parameters, the default values are obtained from the SpringStiffness and SpringLength properties respectively.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NBarycenterGraphLayout
member.summary: The NBarycenterGraphLayout class represents a force directed layout, which implements the barycenter layout method.
member.remarks:
The barycenter layout method splits the input graph into a set of fixed and free vertices. Fixed vertices are nailed to the corners of a strictly convex polygon, while free vertices are placed in the barycenter of their neighbours.
In case there are no fixed vertices this will place all vertices at a single point, which is obviously not a good graph drawing. That is why the barycenter layout needs at least three fixed vertices.
The minimal amount of fixed vertices is specified by the MinFixedVerticesCount property. If the input graph does not have that many fixed vertices, the layout will automatically forefill this requirement. This is done by fixing the vertices with the smallest degree.
The attractive force pulling the vertices towards their barycenter is represented by an instance of the NBarycenterForce class, accessible from the BarycenterForce property.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NForceDirectedGraphLayout
member.summary: The NForceDirectedGraphLayout class is a graph layout, which layouts the graph vertices and edges, according to the forces acting on them. It serves as base class for all types of force directed layouts.
member.remarks:
The force directed layout basically implements an iterative algorithm, which tries to minimize the physical energy (reach equilibrium), enduced by the forces in the provided graph. Different force directed layouts use different sets of forces, however all forces are derived from the base NForce class.
In general the algorithm performs the following steps:
Fixed vertex placement
fixed vertices are such vertices, which cannot be moved in both X and Y directions. Their initial placement is controlled by an instance of the NFixedVertexPlacement class, accessible from the FixedVertexPlacement property.
Free vertex placement
free vertices are such vertices, which can be moved in X or Y directions. Their initial placement is controlled by an instance of the NFreeVertexPlacement class, accessible from the FreeVertexPlacement property.
Iteration phase
the iteration phase is repeated until all enabled forces are activated. At each iteration phase the algorithm tries to reach equilibrium in the number of iterations specified by the MaxIterations property. At each iteration the algorithm first accumulates the forces acting on all vertices and then ask the enviroment to apply them (actually move the vertices). The enviroment is represented by an instance of the NForceEnvironment class, accessible from the ForceEnvironment property.
The force directed layout provides the following optional force model:
Magnetic Field Force
The magnetic field force tries to impose an orientation of the edges in the graph. It is represented by an instance of the NMagneticFieldForce class, accessible from the MagneticFieldForce property respectively.
Repulse Overlapped Force
The repulse overllaped force forces tries to additionally repel overlapping vertices. It is represented by an instance of the NBounceBackForce class, accessible from the BounceBackForce property.
Gravity Force
The gravity force forces tries to attact the vertices to the current barycenter of the graph. It is represented by an instance of the NGravityForce class, accessible from the GravityForce property.
All of the above mentioned forces are by default disabled and their activation pass is set to 1. In this way, if any of those forces is enabled, the graph will be given a chance to relax during the first pass, in which only the primary force model will act.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NSpringGraphLayout
member.summary: The NSpringGraphLayout class represents a force directed layout, which simulates a physical system with spring and electical forces.
member.remarks:
The spring layout represents a classical implementation of a force directed layout, with spring and electicral forces. It allows for many per vertex and per edge settings, which can seamlessly reflect the nature of the graph.
Graph vertices are threated as ellectically charged particles, which repel each other. The electical force aims to ensure that vertices should not be close together. The parameters of the electrical force are controlled by an instance of the NElectricalForce class, accessible from the ElectricalForce property.
Graph edges are threated as springs. Springs aim to ensure that the distance between adjacent vertices is approximately equal to the spring length. The parameters of the spring force are controlled by an instance of the NSpringForce class, accessible from the SpringForce property.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NSpringGraphLayout.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NSpringGraphLayout.NSpringGraphLayoutSchema
member.summary: Schema associated with NSpringGraphLayout

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NSpringGraphLayout.ElectricalForce
member.summary: Gets the electical force, which tries to repel the vertices so that they do not stay too close together

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NSymmetricalGraphLayout
member.summary: The NSymmetricalGraphLayout class is a force directed layout, which simulates a physical system with repulsive and attractive forces, which strives to produce a symmetrical drawing of a graph.
member.remarks:
The symmetrical layout represents an implementation of the Fruchertman and Reingold force directed layout (with some modifications). It uses attractive and repulsive forces, which aim to produce a drawing with uniform distance between each set of connected vertices. Because of that the drawing tends to be symmetrical.
The attractive and repulsive forces are coupled in an instance of the NDesiredDistanceForce class, accessible from the DesiredDistanceForce property.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NClassicalTreeLayout
member.summary: Represents a directed tree layout, which serves as base class for all classical tree layouts.
member.remarks:
In a classical tree layout, the vertex children are always arranged in a row below their parent, in the respective layout direction.
Although in different types of classical tree layouts the depth arrangement of the tree vertices can be different, they all share a VertexSpacing property, which controls the minimal distance between vertices in the breadth layout dimension.
You can specify whether the drawing must be compact in the breadth dimension via the CompactBreadth property. When this property is set to true the layout will analyze each subtree outline and place siblings subtrees with minimal breadth spacing. When this property is set to false the layout will only analyze the subtree bounding box, which increases the layout speed, but also increases the tree drawing area.
Classical tree layouts admit both orthogonal and straight line tree drawings. If the OrthogonalEdgeRouting property is set to true, the edges will be routed in a bus-like fashion. The bus itself can be aligned relatively to the gap, in which it resides with the help of the BusAlignment property.
Classical tree layouts use an uniform parent placement, which is applicable for all parent vertices. The parameters of the parent placement strategy are controlled by an instance of the NParentPlacement class, accessible from the ParentPlacement property.
The PortStyle property specifies the predefined configuration of ports, to which the layout must attempt to glue the edges end-points.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NLayeredTreeLayout
member.summary: The NLayeredTreeLayout class represents a classical tree layout, which arranges the tree levels in layers.
member.remarks:
The layered tree layout places vertices from one level of the tree in a single layer. The depth spacing between adjacent layers is controlled by the LayerSpacing property. The depth alignment of the vertices inside the layer is controlled by the LayerAlignment property.
Additionally, when the OrthogonalEdgeRouting is set to true, you can instruct the layout to consider the bus gap between the layers, instead of the gap between the parent and its top-most child. This is controlled by the BusBetweenLayers property.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NParentPlacement
member.summary: The NParentPlacement class represents an attribute, which is used to encapsulate the horizontal or vertical placement of a parent tree vertex in respect to its children or subtree.
member.remarks:
When the subtree of a parent vertex is layed out, the value of the Anchor property is used to determine a base position (anchor) for the parent vertex to be placed at. This position is generally relative to a metric of the already arranged children or subtree. Then the anchor is additionally offset with the value specified by the Offset property. Finally the parent is aligned to the anchor in accordance to the Alignment property setting.
Note that the above metioned parent placement can be performed either horizontally or vertically, as the containing layout decides.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.Layout.NTipOverTreeLayout
member.summary: The NTipOverTreeLayout class is a directed tree layout, which places the children of a vertex in a single row or column.
member.remarks:
The tip-over tree layout implements an orthogontal tree drawing algorithm, which recursively arranges the children subtrees of a tree vertex in either a single row or a single column.
The children placement can be specified on a per vertex basis. If a vertex does not provide a concrete value for this parameter it is by default obtained from the ChildrenPlacement property.
Unlike classical tree layouts, this type of layout does not use an uniform parent placement. Based on whether the parent children must be arranged in a row or col, the layout uses the instance of the NParentPlacement class, accessible from the RowParentPlacement or the ColParentPlacement properties respectively.

member.summary: Default constructor

member.summary: Reference to the ChildrenPlacement property.

member.summary: Reference to the IndexInLayer property.

member.summary: Reference to the LayerIndex property.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.DockArea
member.summary: Gets or sets the dock area of the shape. The Dock layout uses this value to determine the area to which to dock the shape. Applicable to 2D shapes only. By default Top.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.WrapFlowBreak
member.summary: Gets or sets whether flow layouts should break after this shape. The WrapFlow and Table layouts uses this value to determine whether they should make a new lane after the shape. Applicable to 2D shapes only. By default false.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.IndexInLayer
member.summary: Gets or sets the index of the vertex in the layer.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.LayerIndex
member.summary: Determines layer index of the node when Layered Graph Layout is applied. By default set to -1, which means that the index will be determined automatically.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.TipOverChildrenPlacement
member.summary: Gets or sets the way in which the TipOver tree layout arranges the shape children. Applicable only to 2D shapes. By default set to Row.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.XMoveable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether force directed layouts are allowed to move the shape in the X direction. Applicable to 2D shapes only. By default true.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.YMoveable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether force directed layouts are allowed to move the shape in the Y direction. Applicable to 2D shapes only. By default true.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.MagnetizationType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of magnetization of the 1D shape. Applicable only to 1D shapes.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.ElectricalCharge
member.summary: Gets or sets the ellectrical charge of the shape. In Spring Graph Layouts this affects the strength with which vertex repels other vertices. Applicable to 2D Shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.SpringStiffness
member.summary: Gets or sets the spring stiffness of the shape. In Spring Graph Layouts this affects the strength with which edge repels or attracts the connected vertices. Applicable to 1D Shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.SpringLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the spring length of the shape. In Spring Graph Layouts this affects the natural length of the spring. The layout tries to arrange the vertices connected by this edge at this distance. Applicable to 1D Shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NLayoutData.Mass
member.summary: Gets or sets the mass of the shape. In Force Directed Layouts this affects the strength with which vertex is attracted to the current barycenter of the graph. Applicable to 2D Shapes only.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NDrawBoxCommand
member.summary: A geometry command that serves as base class for draw box commands such as DrawRectangle, DrawEllipse, DrawPolyline, DrawPolygon and DrawPath.
member.remarks: Box commands are used for the more efficient drawing of geometries that have lots of vertices. The figure placement is defined by four sides (left, top, right and bottom). Each specific command outputs an open or closed figure or even an entire path, that aims to fill this box.

member.summary: Reference to the Relative property

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NGeometryCommand.Relative
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the command coordinates are expressed in absolute or relative values. By default set to false, meaning that command coordinates are in absolute shape coordinates.
member.remarks:
It is often required to make 2D shapes whose geometry coordinates are expressed relatively to the shape Width and Height. In such cases you may set the Relative property to true.
For example: if Relative is set to false, to define a point in the center of the shape you can set the "Width*0.5" and "Height*0.5" expressions to the X and Y coordindates of a command. This syntax requires one expressions per point coordinate.
if Relative is set to true, to define a point in the center of the shape you can set the X property to 0.5 and the Y property to 0.5. This syntax does not require expressions.

member.summary: Gets the item permissions mask or simply the mask of operations that the user can perform with the item. Certain diagram items may additionally drop certain permissions as they see fit.

member.summary: Sets the protection properties of this item to reflect the specified protection mask.

member.summary: Gets the local pin point position (in local coordinates)

member.summary: Sets the local pin point position (in local coordinates). By default the local pin point is specified relatively to the shape width and height. This implementation sets proportional expressions to the LocPinX and LocPinY properties.

member.summary: Gets the pin point position (in parent coordinates)

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NShape.GetPinPointInPage
member.summary: Gets the pin point position in page coordinates

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NShape.SetPinPoint(Nevron.Nov.Graphics.NPoint)
member.summary: Sets the pin point position (in parent coordinates). This operation unglues the shape from its master (if any). If the shape resides in a group, the Pin is expressed as factor expressions of the group dimensions. If the shape resides in a page, the Pin is set to constant values.
member.param: new pin point position (in parent coordinates)

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NShape.SetAngle(Nevron.Nov.NAngle)
member.summary: Sets the shape angle relatively to its parent (i.e. Page or Group). This operation unglues the shape from its master (if any). If the shape is inside the page, this method sets a constant value to the Angle property. If the shape is inside a group, this method also updates the expressions of the Width and Height properties, depending on the ResizeInGroup setting.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NShape.Rotate(Nevron.Nov.NAngle)
member.summary: Rotates the shape with the specified angle amount. Internally this method calls SetAngle with a value equal to Angle + angle.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NShape.GlueMasterPortToPort(Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NPort,Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NPort)
member.summary: Glues (connects) a port of this shape to a port of the master shape. This type of glue translates the shape to match the port locations, and rotates the shape to match the port directions.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NShape.UnglueFromMaster
member.summary: Unglues (disconnects) the outward connection of this shape if any.

remarks.para: The outward connection for a shape controls the shape PinX, PinY and Angle properties by binding them to the aspect and element defined by the MasterElementRef and MasterGlue properties.

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NShape.Init1DShape(Nevron.Nov.Diagram.EN1DShapeXForm)
member.summary:
Helper method for setting up a 1D shape. Sets the ShapeType to 1D.
If xformType is Vector, the shape transform is initialized as a vector connecting the begin and end points, such that: Binds the Width to the distance between the Begin and End points. Binds the Angle to the angle formed by the line connecting the Begin and End points and the X axis. Binds the PinX and PinY to the middle point of the line connecting the Begin and End points. Binds the LocPinX and LocPinY to the center of the shape local alignment box.
If xformType is Box, the shape transform is initialized as a vector connecting the begin and end points, such that: Binds the Width to the X distance between the Begin and End points. Binds the Height to the Y distance between the Begin and End points. Sets the angle to zero. Binds the PinX and PinY to the middle point of the line connecting the Begin and End points. Binds the LocPinX and LocPinY to the center of the shape.

member.summary: Gets or sets model that defines this connector geometry.

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NRoutableConnector.AllowLayoutsReroute
member.summary: Gets or sets whether layouts are allowed to reroute the connector. By default set to true.
member.remarks: Typically each layout has some predefined routing logic. That is why when routable connectors that allow reroute are routed by the layout, their RerouteMode is set to Never, and their model is defined by the layout. If you wish to protect a specific connector from this default behavior, you can set this property to false.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NDrawing
member.summary: Represents an interactive drawing, that consists of pages. A drawing is the root element inside a NDrawingDocument.
member.remarks: Each drawing consists of pages that are accessible from the Pages property. Of all pages in a drawing only one can be active at time. The active page is specified by its index, via the ActivePageIndex property. The currently active page is accessible from the ActivePage property.

member.summary: Moves the preview of the selected items to the position specified by dragPos. If preview is not created, it is created if the mustCreatePreview is true, or the mouse has moved a certain amount from the tool activation position. Finally if the preview is created, it is started with the location specified by startPos parameter.
member.param: position to move preview to (in page coordinates)
position to start preview from (in page coordinates)

member.summary: Activates the tool

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NPageSelection
member.summary: Represents the currently selected items of a page.

member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: M:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NPageSelection.RegionSelect(Nevron.Nov.DataStructures.NList{Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NDiagramItem})
member.summary: Performs a region node selection
member.remarks:
This method takes into account the current Control and Shift key states and performs the following actions:
1. If the CTRL key is pressed it will toggle the node selection state
2. If the SHIFT key is pressed it will multi select the specified node
3. If no key modifier is pressed it will clear the selection and multi select the specified node

member.name: P:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NPort.Relative
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the port coordinates are expressed in absolute or relative values. By default set to false, meaning that command coordinates are in absolute shape coordinates.
member.remarks:
It is often required to make ports the coordinates of which are expressed relatively to the shape Width and Height. In such cases you may set the Relative property to true.
For example: if Relative is set to false, to define a port in the center of the shape you can set the "Width*0.5" and "Height*0.5" expressions to the X and Y coordindates of the port. This syntax requires one expressions per port coordinate.
if Relative is set to true, to define a port in the center of the shape you can set the X property to 0.5 and the Y property to 0.5. This syntax does not require expressions.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGeometryEndDirection.None
member.summary: The geometry cannot provide a direction for its start or end.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGeometryEndDirection.Horizontal
member.summary: The geometry direction for the start or end is horizontal.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGeometryEndDirection.Vertical
member.summary: The geometry direction for the start or end is vertical.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGeometryEndDirection.Automatic
member.summary: The geometry direction for the start or end is automatically determined.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENDefaultShapeGlue
member.summary: Enumerates the default ways in which a connector begin or end point is by default glued the shape via shape-to-shape connections.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENDefaultShapeGlue.None
member.summary: By default the shape does not allow shape to shape connections.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENDefaultShapeGlue.Automatic
member.summary:
The Begin or End point of the connectors are glued automatically depending on the shape type, geometry and ports.
If case the shape is a 2D shape:
If the shape has ports, glues to the nearest port. Otherwise glues to the shape box intersection.
If case the shape is a 1D shape:
If the shape has ports, glues to the nearest port. If the shape geometry has closed figures -> glues to the shape line center. Otherwise -> glues to the shape contour middle.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENDefaultShapeGlue.GlueToGeometryIntersection
member.summary: The Begin or End point of the connectors are glued to the contour (outline) of the shape geometry.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENDefaultShapeGlue.GlueToBoxIntersection
member.summary: The Begin or End point of the connectors are glued to the contour (outline) of the shape box.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENDefaultShapeGlue.GlueToNearestPort
member.summary: The Begin or End point of the connectors are glued to the nearest port of the shape.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENDefaultShapeGlue.GlueToBoxCenter
member.summary: The Begin or End point of the connectors are glued to the nearest port of the shape.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENRoutableConnectorRerouteMode
member.summary: Enumerates the modes in which a route can be automatically rerouted

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENRoutableConnectorRerouteMode.Never
member.summary: The route is never automatically rerouted - it is up to the user to manage its points or call the Reroute method

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENRoutableConnectorRerouteMode.Always
member.summary: The route is automatically rerouted whenever any of the obstacles have changed (e.g. there is a chance for the route to be rerouted more efficiently)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENRoutableConnectorRerouteMode.WhenNeeded
member.summary: The route is rerouted whenever an obstacle is placed on it or the shapes to which it is connected are moved or have changed

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENCoordinateBehavior
member.summary: Defines the possible ways in which points X and Y coordinates can behave

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENCoordinateBehavior.Proportional
member.summary: The coordinate is defined proportionally to the respective dimension (Width or Height). For example Height*0.6.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENCoordinateBehavior.Locked
member.summary: The coordinate is locked to its original value. Nevron does not update this coordinate.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENCoordinateBehavior.OffsetFromMin
member.summary: The coordinate is defined with a constant distance from the near side (Left or Top)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENCoordinateBehavior.OffsetFromMid
member.summary: The coordinate is defined with a constant distance from the center (CenterX or CenterY).

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENCoordinateBehavior.OffsetFromMax
member.summary: The coordinate is defined with a constant distance from the far side (Right or Bottom)

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENResizeInGroup
member.summary: Enumerates the ways in which Nevron will update the shape transformation and dimensions, when a shape, which resides in a group is resized.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENResizeInGroup.UseGroupSettings
member.summary: Uses the settings of the group in which the shape resides. In this mode the shape will use the NGroup.ResizeShapes setting.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENResizeInGroup.RepositionOnly
member.summary: The Pin will be expressed relatively to the group Width and Height. The Shape Width and Height are set to constant values.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENResizeInGroup.ScaleAndReposition
member.summary: The Pin will be expressed relatively to the group Width and Height. The Shape Width will be expressed relatively to the group Width and Height.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGroupResizeShapes
member.summary: Enumerates the default way in which shapes in groups are resized.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGroupResizeShapes.RepositionOnly
member.summary: Repositions the shape.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGroupResizeShapes.ScaleAndReposition
member.summary: Scales and repositions the shape.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGroupSelectionMode
member.summary: Enumerates the default way in which shapes in groups are resized.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGroupSelectionMode.GroupOnly
member.summary: Specifies that when you click a group, only the group is selected. You cannot select the individual shapes within a group.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGroupSelectionMode.GroupFirst
member.summary: Specifies that when you click a group, the group is selected first. If you click again, you can select an individual shape. Group first is the default behavior for most groups.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGroupSelectionMode.ShapesFirst
member.summary: Specifies that when you click a group, you select the individual shape that you're pointing to. You must click the bounding box around the group to select the group itself.

member.summary: The elements are displayed behind the member shapes.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENGroupElementsZOrder.AboveShapes
member.summary: The elements are displayed above the member shapes.

member.summary: Defines the possible shape types

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeType.Shape1D
member.summary: 1D shape - a shape that behaves as a line connecting 2D shapes.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeType.Shape2D
member.summary: 2D shape - a shape that behaves as a box.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.EN1DShapeXForm
member.summary: Enumerates the predefined ways in which a 1D shape transform can be initialized.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.EN1DShapeXForm.Vector
member.summary: The 1D shape transform is initialized as a vector connecting the begin and end points, such that: Binds the Width to the distance between the Begin and End points. Binds the Angle to the angle formed by the line connecting the Begin and End points and the X axis. Binds the PinX and PinY to the middle point of the line connecting the Begin and End points. Binds the LocPinX and LocPinY to the center of the shape local alignment box.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.EN1DShapeXForm.Box
member.summary: The 1D shape transform is initialized as a box formed by the begin and end points, such that: Binds the Width to the X distance between the Begin and End points. Binds the Height to the Y distance between the Begin and End points. Binds the PinX and PinY to the middle point of the line connecting the Begin and End points. Binds the LocPinX and LocPinY to the center of the shape. Sets the angle to zero.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.EN1DShapeXForm.BoxAbsolute
member.summary: The 1D shape transform is initialized as a box formed by the begin and end points, such that: Binds the Width to the absolute X distance between the Begin and End points. Binds the Height to the absolute Y distance between the Begin and End points. Binds the PinX and PinY to the middle point of the line connecting the Begin and End points. Binds the LocPinX and LocPinY to the center of the shape. Sets the angle to zero.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockXForm
member.summary: Enumerates the predefined ways in which a shape text block transform can be initialized.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockXForm.ShapeBox
member.summary: The text block is sized and positioned inside the shape Width/Height box. This has the following effect: Binds the Width and Height properties to the Width and Height of the shape. Binds the LocPinX and LocPinY of the text block to the center of the text block. Binds the PinX and PinX of the text block to the center of the shape. Sets the angle to zero.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockXForm.ShapeLineMiddle
member.summary: The text block is sized to the shape desired size. Binds the LocPinX and LocPinY of the text block to the center of the text block. Binds the PinX and PinX of the shape line middle (the line connecting the Begin and End points). Binds the angle to the shape line angle.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockXForm.GeometryContourMiddle
member.summary: The text block is sized to the shape desired size. Binds the LocPinX and LocPinY of the text block to the center of the text block. Binds the PinX and PinX of the shape geometry contour middle. Binds the angle to the shape geometry contour angle in the middle.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockXForm.CustomPin
member.summary: The text block is sized to the shape desired size. Binds the LocPinX and LocPinY of the text block to the center of the text block. Leaves the PinX and PinX to be specified by the user. Sets the angle to zero.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockResizeMode
member.summary: Enumerates the possible ways in which a text block be resized.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockResizeMode.None
member.summary: The text block is not automatically resized.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockResizeMode.ShapeSize
member.summary: The text block is automatically resized to the size of the owner shape.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockResizeMode.TextSize
member.summary: The text block is resized to its desired size.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENTextBlockResizeMode.ShapeWidthTextHeight
member.summary: The text block width is resized to size of the owner shape, while the text block height is resized to the desired text block size.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENPortGlueMode
member.summary: Defines the possible port types

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENPortGlueMode.Inward
member.summary: Inward ports can be connected to end-points and outward ports of other shapes.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENPortGlueMode.Outward
member.summary: Outward ports can be connected only with inward ports of other shapes.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENPortGlueMode.InwardAndOutward
member.summary: Inward and Outward ports behave as a mixture of the other two types

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENPortFlowMode
member.summary: Defines the port flow type -

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENPortFlowMode.Input
member.summary: An input port can be connected only to other Output ports and other shapes End points.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENPortFlowMode.Output
member.summary: An output port can be connected only to other Input ports and other shapes Begin points.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENPortFlowMode.InputOutput
member.summary: The port is of input-output type.

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves
member.summary: A masked enumerations which defines the shapes that must be moved together with a certain shape.

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.ReflexiveShapes
member.summary: Translate with shapes which reflex it (e.g. 1D shapes whose both plugs are connected to the shape)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.IncomingShapes
member.summary: Translate with the incoming shapes (e.g. 1D shapes whose end plug is connected to the shape)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.OutgoingShapes
member.summary: Translate with the outgoing shapes (e.g. 1D shapes whose start plug is connected to the shape)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.FromShape
member.summary: Translate with the FROM shape (e.g. the shape to which the start plug is connected). Applicable for 1D shapes

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.ToShape
member.summary: Translate with the TO shape (e.g. the shape to which the end plug is connected)). Applicable for 1D shapes

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.DestinationShapes
member.summary: Translate with destination shapes (e.g. the shapes which are connected to the end plug of outgoing shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.SourceShapes
member.summary: Translate with source shapes (e.g. the shapes which are connected to the start plug of incoming shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.SuccessorShapes
member.summary: Translate with successor shapes (e.g. DestinationShapes + the successor shapes of the destination shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.PredecessorShapes
member.summary: Translate with predecessor shapes (e.g. SourceShapes + the predecessor shapes of the source shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.AccessibleShapes
member.summary: Translate with all accessible shapes (e.g. NeighbourShapes + the accessible shapes of the neighbour shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.All
member.summary: All

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.ConnectedShapes
member.summary: Translate with all possible connected shapes (e.g. IncomingShapes + OutgoingShapes + FromShape + ToShape)

member.name: F:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.ENShapeMoveSlaves.NeighbourShapes
member.summary: Translate with neighbour shapes (e.g. DestinationShapes + SourceShapes)

member.name: T:Nevron.Nov.Diagram.NGeometry
member.summary: Represents a shape geometry. The geometry defines a dynamically constructed graphics path, which is created by the geometry child commands.
member.remarks:
There are two ways in which you can define the path of a geometry:
With Plotter Commands
Plotter commands such as NMoveTo, NLineTo, NArcTo etc. provide the ability define dynamic geometries, that are driven by expressions, because each aspect of a plotter command is controlled by a property to which you can assign an expression.
With DrawBox Commands
DrawBox commands such as NDrawRectangle, NDrawEllipse, NDrawPolygon, NDrawPolyline and NDrawPath provide the ability to draw geometries with many vertices, that stretch to a box inside the shape coordinate system. DrawBox commands are commonly used when you create clip-art shapes.
